page.title: 02SCENERY AROUND ALTON
page.content: The scenery in this part of the Churnet Valley is the most attractive in Staffordshire.Millstone Grit forms the rounded hills which rise above Farley while the remainder of the high ground is produced by New Red Sandstone which gives the typical brown-red pebbly sandstone outcrops.Hilly landscape is produced by the steep- sided stream valleys and dry valleys, (formed during the Ice Age), cutting through the sandstones.The River Churnet is the main feature with a steep sided valley enclosing a 200 metre wide flat floor, filled with alluvium.Buildings add to the attractiveness of the landscape. Alton Castle towers above the valley so earning it the title of"The Rhineland of Staffordshire".The ruined shell of Alton Towers,built by the Earl of Shrewsbury,and now being restored,comes into view from many vantage points.
